title: Next Steps
text:
So what are our next steps from here?

Additonal Information to Capture

Would love to capture more information about exits to better track. One that would be interesting is capturing when we have ‘regrettable loss’, or better detailing what characteristics would make an exit more regettable for the organization.
Would be interesting to bring in the exit interview data to augment the analysis to dig further into employee’s decisions to leave.
For our employee enagement survey, it would be helpful to think about gathering more detailed feedback around employee perceptions. (ie something like: “are you fairly compensated for the work you perform?”, with the goal of understanding how an across the board raise might impact their perceptions).



Testing Hypotheses

We would want to measure the turnover after we make this policy change to determine if it had the intended affect.

Know that this would be a long feedback loop as we would want to wait at least a month before testing again.
Could utilize a chi-sqare test to test for differences.




Questions to consider:

Would a 6% raise even impact employee satisfaction

How would it compare to the cost of living due to inflation?
Would questions in the employee engagement survey could capture employee perception here?

title: Overview
text:
Presentation last built on: 2025-10-14



Note from Phil
I am aiming to provide a clear and instructive analysis to Sr Leadership, mixing both written prose and visuals to provide an artifact for later viewing as well as a tool to center the conversation for this decision. I will start with the high level recommendation and then provide the steps for how we get there, knowing that depending on the leader’s availability, sometimes there is only time for the analysis and sometimes it’s desired to know how we got to the answer.
I have intentionally designed this to be a code driven analysis in order to ensure that both the analysis is reproducible as well as that the code is reusable. It has been a common occurance for me where I have provided an analysis, we’ve made a decision and then a year later we want to evaluate the results. By this solution being code based, we are able to quickly recreate the analysis and update with the necessary data without having to wonder if some data was omited due to outliers or if we intentionally just focused on a specific population.
Because this presentation is meant for Sr Leadership I have intentionally removed most code, except for situations where it would be instructive or in more of of the detailed appendix. If you would like to review the code, please visit the code repository on Github by clicking on the icon on the top right and navigating to the “Source Code” link.
Thanks for following along!
-phil walker

Below is the provided problem statement. This is what we will use as our driving focus for this analysis.

You are a Senior HR Data & Insights Consultant and have been asked to assist senior HR leadership make a decision regarding a planned policy change.



Senior leadership is concerned with the on-going impact the pandemic and “Great Resignation” has had on the workforce. There is a pervasive belief that turnover has been steadily on the rise over the past five years, and recent high-profile terminations among some of the organization’s top performers have raised questions regarding the organization’s retention strategy.
Senior leaders believe compensation is driving turnover and have proposed implementing an across the board annual raise of 6% at the start of next year to counteract the effect of inflation.
You have one week to clean, review, and analyze the provided data to help senior leadership understand the current turnover landscape, the cost of their proposal, and whether the proposed retention strategy will have the desired impact.

All 4 of the survey repsonses are decently correlated with terminations.

Because the correlations are negative, we would say that in general that the lower the response (closer to strongly disagree) that the higher the likelihood of an employee exiting.
